comments.commentBody: Seriously, if someone told you back in June that Trump could get 24% in Iowa and finish 3 points behind the winner in second, and spend a miniscule amount of time and resources in Iowa, you would say no way.  Frankly, I am amazed that Trump did as well as he did in Iowa.  I thought when he announced his campaign back in June that he would just skip Iowa altogether.  Remember, Iowan Republicans would prefer to elect a Pastor-in-Chief more than anything else.  Ted Cruz stated that he is against ethanol and will get rid of it as President, but he won despite this because he invoked God so much in the campaign you would have thought God was his running mate.

Amazing that two states that bear no resemblance to the American population carry so much weight. A fairer competition would be in five swing states: Ohio, Pennsylvania, Michigan, North Carolina, and Florida, say, or substitute Missouri and Colorado. The idea that fewer people than live in Staten Island can have so much influence is insane and counter-productive.

Mr. Trump's strength is an illusion. His balloon popped last night in Iowa when he became - oh, that horror of horrors - "a loser" to Ted Cruz. His decision to walk away from the last Republican debate in his tantrum against Fox News and because he disliked anchor Megyn Kelly obviously cost him many votes last night. Marco Rubio finished in third place, but he is not a strong candidate and with the GOP Primary in New Hampshire coming up 9 February, it will be surprising if Rubio can best the conservative candidates - JEB!, Kasich,  and Christie - who have been stumping in the Granite State for weeks.  As for Trump, the elephant in the room, one hopes he will back out gracefully.

Ted Cruz's win last night in Iowa makes me wonder if we really need God when someone can win election with total hatred .

And ironically all the words that he invokes, are coming out of the mouth of a southern Baptist Christian, born to a father who is a Christian preacher .

So from the above information, we can easily surmise about which direction the Republican party is going.

If the highly Evangelicals in Iowa can elect a huckster called Ted Cruz as their chosen one, I'm quite sure that they would've chosen Hitler too if he was seeking their votes in 1939 in Iowa and not in Germany.

Hitler was peddling extreme hatred towards the Jews as Cruz and company are peddling hatred towards the Muslims now.

For that I really wonder what we're going to tell to our non-Christian voters that Christianity is the most peaceful religion and they should embrace the same religion and vote candidates like Cruz and Trump and not Jeb.

If that is the case, Jesus would've come among us long time back and rescued us from totally evil monsters like Adolf Hitler.

In the same context, we must know that we're the ones who're denying Jesus the access to our society, our country and the whole world when we elect politicians who're preaching hatred and annihilation of people who're different than us , in the matters of color of their skin, their different culture and the language they speak and also the God they pray to.

Trust me when I say, that's not what Jesus wanted from us.

Rubio won. It leaves me confounded. Who is this guy except a pretty face who can speak well on TV. Would make a great newscaster on Fox. He came on strong with his "I hate Hillary and Obama" in the previous weeks - and may have produced the results they did yesterday. I am as befuddled as the Jeb camp.

None of the top three contenders among Republicans spell a better future for America. They speak of a return to the past, a distant past, where America worked well for only a fraction of people.

And half of all democrats voted for a candidate who promised a completely free lunch to the young on the backs of a criminal class of Americans. There was no other constituency he addressed.

Rubio may have won; American people lost big yesterday.

Kalidan

Come On. All the reporters and pundits who don't like Trump personally and predicted his demise long ago are not so secretly thrilled to call showing a "defeat." Second place in a field that large is a defeat?

As Yogi said, "I Ain't over til it's over." And you can bet that New Hampshire voters, proud of their previous independent votes, will take great pleasure in defying all the predictions of Trump's doom to vote for him in the face of media gloating about the "humbling" he supposedly endured.

The the big losers in Iowa were not just certain politicians, but the pollsters. The surprise victories of David Cameron in the UK and Benjamin Netanyahu in Israel last year are just two recent examples of the growing unreliability of polls. Even Mitt Romney's pollsters predicted his victory in 2012, right to the bitter end. Polls are becoming unwieldy, prohibitively expensive, and increasingly inaccurate tools for the polling companies, not to mention more and more irritating for the general public who are bombarded with them ad nauseum.

Mr. Rubio is young, listens to his elders, and can sign his name.  What more could the billionaire oligarchs ask for? I'd hate to see a corporatist general election.  But on the D side, Bernie is neck-and-neck with Hillary coming from waaaay behind in the home stretch.  Giddyyup, Bernie!
Trump carelessly allowed a woman to defeat him! By not participating in the last round, he wrote his own defeat.

"Mr. Trump fared especially poorly among voters who decided over the last week — since his decision not to participate in the final presidential debate before the caucuses."

Trying to imagine the thought process that goes into choosing one of these GOP clowns to lead the FREE FREAKN WORLD!

The most important outcome is that Trump's carefully constructed image of always being a "winner" has been punctured. For some of his followers that will be like a cold shower in the harsh reality of the morning after.

Donald Trump lost nothing in Iowa.  Iowa isn't even an election it's a poll of highly engaged voters.  In the Republican case it's generally highly engaged, highly religious conservatives.  These voters don't even represent a large portion of Republicans let alone Republicans in NH and South Carolina where votes are actually cast by typical voters.
Thank you, Megyn Kelly!

This is the part of the political system where they weed out the candidates who represent the will of the people. It will be Ted Cruz and Hillary representing Goldman Sachs.  The eventual winner is meaningless.
Let us hope that D. Trump learns from this to drop the personal attacks and entrench himself and his conversation on the issues only.  We will see.  Glad to see the field narrowing, finally.

You said "irregular voters who might not show up in a primary.Tonight, there’s reason to believe their hopes just might be well founded".With a 3 % win for Cruz and Iowa being the weakest state for Trump from the begining, what u said is not very smart.

Trump a loser?  Don't be silly, Trump planned all along to be in second place, for Donald wanted to give Cruz a false lead, knowing he will eliminate him in New Hampshire. Donald has told us, he never, ever loses. It is something he never has done, like ask for forgiveness.

Trump will get the last laugh. As I recall just a short time ago Trump was being called a Clown. Why wasn't your headline "The Clown loses"? I know why. In the first real primary, the "Clown" is going to win and will win the one after that and the one after that.
So, just as I suspected. Trump's support may look wide, but it's shallow. Sort of like him, come to think of it.
There are "moderate" Republicans?
167,000 people is not a way to elect a party leader. American democracy has a great deal of onion layers in need of pruning.

Trump expended near zero effort in creating a ground organization.

Dominating the polls cannot translate into votes if your supporters do not know where and when to go and vote.

Duh.
Iowa picks losers. That's there tradition.
Am I wrong but do I hear most tv news anchors and candidates alike say "pundints" rather than pundits?

At what stage in the campaign will respectable news outlets stop analyzing the Republican race with a veil of "objectivity" and call it out for the circus side show that it has become? Trump and Cruz's candidacies go well above and beyond what any political satires could have ever imagined. There are serious candidates like Kasich out there with more grounded views that can sure use the endorsement of the NYT, like it has done, but would also gain from a more honest dissection of each campaign's and candidate's level of lucidity. "Neutral" news items like these focusing solely on the arithmetic of the campaigns do this country and potentially the world a huge disservice. You are electing the leader of one of the world's most powerful nations people. The media should embrace its role in the US's democratic process more fully and start more critical reporting even when the story seems bland.
